subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit 4 - "before all tests" check turns off all tests
msgSnippet: ... Annotations enable a cleaner way to do this:  class-scoped annotations. In TestNG, annotations such as @Test can be specified at the class level, which
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Jeff Grigg

> Good points.
>
> Something I've done to switch banks of tests on and off is to
> have them all inherit from a new class that is a child of
> TestCase, and then I can override 'run(...)', 'runBare()' or
> 'runTest()' to check a flag and then runs the test (by
> calling the super class TestCase
> implementation) or skips is.

Annotations enable a cleaner way to do this: class-scoped annotations.

In TestNG, annotations such as @Test can be specified at the class level,
which means they now apply to all the public methods of the class. It makes
it easier to specify bulk settings, such as group membership:

Instead of:

public class Test1 {
@Test(groups = { "a", "b"})
public void f1() {
}

@Test(groups = { "a", "b"})
public void f2() {
}
}

You write:

@Test(groups = {"a", "b"})
public class Test1 {
public void f1() {
}

public void f2() {
}
}

With this method disabling an entire class boils down to modifying one flag:

@Test(groups = {"a", "b"}, enabled = false)
public class Test1 {
public void f1() {
}

public void f2() {
}
}

(of course, I would argue that a better solution is to disable this class at
runtime, but this doesn't seem to be a direction that JUnit4 is headed
toward)

All of this is day-to-day test maintenance, you shouldn't have to do complex
stuff such as overriding runBare() to do it.

> I've used this primarily to support configuration flags like
> "run the tests that connect to the database" (or not) and
> "run the really time-consuming tests" (or not).

Tests of groups are clearly a better way to do this (and of course, they can
also be specified at the class level).
